Topic.Title: Hello, Blue Monday.

Message.Msg: BAC will continue to do what it has been doing, focus on getting more of the wallet of it's retail customers. That process takes time, but the very fact that most customers have remained loyal despite everything that's been going on says a lot. The expectation of many on this board was that BAC would lose customers hand over fist, but that just hasn't happened. They continue to roll out trend setting ATMs, new banking center models, etc. The key is to build on their current customer base. However, in the meantime, they will continue to be held down as they work through all the mistakes of the past. These aren't going away quickly, so you have to have a long view to see where the bank is headed.

Topic.Title: We will see 15 VERY soon!

No one here has ever pirated my ID (though I won't be surprised if it happens sooner rather than later) , nor do I post under multiple IDs, nor have I EVER posted under anything but fish2kill, despite being accused here at least daily of doing and having done both. I stopped playing the ponies years ago because I SUCKED at it, but I'd genuinely like to learn enough to dabble without getting killed. Besides, I also have an huge albatross to lug around....I'm one of those contemptible 'moral' investors who refuses to invest in German lampshade manufacturers even when everything else is making money hand-over-fist with them. Every one of us makes his or her own moral judgements according to their own values. If I try to nudge or beat people into re-examing theirs, well sorry - sue me. In MY view BAC is only 1 small step above the lampshade factories, but I ain't likely to win any converts with MY persuasive style. What offends me above all else though is the paucity of reason and logic on these boards, and the lack of a level playing field in the markets. Believe me or not; that's entirely up to you, but there it is and you're all free to like it or lump it.

Topic.Title: Ah, the Long Blue Stain!

Message.Msg: Mine was aUSAF uniform, 1970-73, F-4 Weapons Controls Systems mech/tech AFSC 32251P with a combat upgrade to 7-level (with only 1 1/2 years of flightline experience at the time) at Udorn in 1972. Key player supporting Linebacker I & II. AF rightly didn't trust me to carry a gun (but trusted me to work on their frontline fighters LOL). Never shot at anything except targets in basic (perfect 60/60) but I've taken hostile fire. All the killing I'm responsible for was done 2nd-hand at great distances with no accounting, but I'd wager there are Phantom fuel tanks'-worth of VC and civilian blood on my hands. Thank god for creative book-keeping, and thank you for your service. Mine was given reluctantly, but not half-heartedly. Have a nice day.

Message.Title: Sebelius: I'm Not Signing Up for Obamacare
Message.Msg: In an interview with CNN's Dr. Sanjay Gupta Tuesday night, Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius said she won't be enrolling in the problem-plagued health insurance system that she was charged to implement. "I have created an account on the site. I have not tried signing up, because I have insurance," she told Gupta. But Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) says government officials like Sebelius should be required to live under the same laws they impose on everyone else.

Topic.Title: Hello, Blue Monday.

Message.Msg: Thanks for responding, tigger. At least you've confirmed my premise, if not my conclusion. Inertia accounts for the retention of existing customers (yours truly excepted, and switching banks was indeed a royal pain and my own inertia took a year for me to overcome), and as you stated clearly and I only mentioned in passing, the key to BAC's future lies in adding new customers to its base. I believe that BAC's egregious past behavior, along with its current and well-documented bad behavior and absence of business ethics (its dependence on politically-bestowed tax loopholes, paid lobbyists and purchased legislators, special tax credits, velvet-gloved financial regulations and regulators, bailouts, QE handouts, etc) have soured those customers' perception of this firm (remember that the bulk of them are YOUNG) to the point where BAC is the LAST place on earth they'd ever keep OR invest their own (scarce) funds. The Milennials are in deep financial doo-doo, and pretty united in their assessment of who and what put them there. This is the message I came to BAC with almost 3 years ago, and I've only seen it gaining strength over time. Most of them wouldn't be caught dead pumping gas from a BP station into their 20-year old Tercels, and I don't think all the perks and convenience in the world are going to overcome their thoroughly jaundiced view of this bank. I could be wrong; you could be right, but that's my read. Peace out.

He wrote a paper in June, 2007 entitled "Historic turning points in real estate." As I remember, his thesis was booms end when there is a sudden psychological shift in investors' behavior the timing which is impossible to predict. But history shows it will happen with some regularity.
